reference_answer:
Emma Darwin (née Wedgwood) had a significant relationship with Charles Darwin that was rooted in both family ties and long-standing acquaintance. They were first cousins, sharing grandparents Josiah and Sarah Wedgwood, which made their families closely allied. This familial connection meant they were acquainted from childhood, growing up together within the same social circles.

The significance of their relationship is multifaceted:

1. **Familial Connection**: As first cousins, Emma and Charles shared a deep-rooted family bond that was strengthened by their upbringing in prominent families—the Wedgwoods and Darwins—both influential in their own right. The Wedgwood family's success in pottery and the Darwin family's prominence provided a strong foundation for their relationship.

2. **Childhood Acquaintance**: Their shared childhood experiences, including visits to relatives like Aunt Jessie (Madame de Sismondi) and time spent together during family tours of Europe, fostered familiarity and closeness from an early age. These interactions allowed them to develop a mutual understanding and bond that would later support their marriage.

3. **Supportive Partnership**: Their relationship evolved into a supportive partnership when they married on 29 January 1839. Emma played a crucial role in Charles's life, especially during his scientific endeavors. She supported him through the challenges of his work and personal life, including coping with the death of family members like her sister Fanny.

4. **Family Life**: Together, they had ten children, seven of whom survived to adulthood. This large family required Emma's nurturing skills and resilience, which were evident in her earlier life when she helped care for their mother during illness.

Overall, Emma Darwin's relationship with Charles was significant not only because of their familial connection but also due to the enduring support and partnership they provided each other throughout their lives.

query: Describe the evolution of Charles Darwin's views on religion as influenced by his marriage to Emma, including how they maintained open communication about their beliefs despite differing perspectives.
reference_contexts:
['== Religious views ==
Emma's religious beliefs were founded on Unitarianism, which emphasises inner feeling over the authority of religious texts or doctrine. Her views were not simple and unwavering, and were the result of intensive study and questioning.
Darwin was open about his scepticism before they became engaged, and she discussed with him the tension between her fears that differences of belief would separate them, and her desire to be close and openly share ideas. Following their marriage, they shared discussions about Christianity for several years. She valued his openness, and his genuine uncertainty regarding the existence and nature of God, which gradually developed into agnosticism. This may have been a bond between them, without necessarily resolving the tensions between their views.

By early 1837 Charles Darwin was already speculating on transmutation of species. Having decided to marry, he visited Emma on 29 July 1838 and told her of his ideas on transmutation. On 11 November 1838, he returned and proposed to Emma. Again he discussed his ideas, and about ten days later she wrote to him: "When I am with you I think all melancholy thoughts keep out of my head but since you are gone some sad ones have forced themselves in, of fear that our opinions on the most important subject should differ widely. My reason tells me that honest & conscientious doubts cannot be a sin, but I feel it would be a painful void between us. I thank you from my heart for your openness with me & I should dread the feeling that you were concealing your opinions from the fear of giving me pain. It is perhaps foolish of me to say this much but my own dear Charley we now do belong to each other & I cannot help being open with you. Will you do me a favour? yes I am sure you will, it is to read our Saviour's farewell discourse to his disciples which begins at the end of the 13th Chap of John. It is so full of love to them & devotion & every beautiful feeling. It is the part of the New Testament I love best. This is a whim of mine it would give me great pleasure, though I can hardly tell why I don't wish you to give me your opinion about it."
Darwin had already wondered about the materialism implied by his ideas. The letter shows Emma's tension between her fears that differences of belief would separate them, and her desire to be close and openly share ideas. Emma cherished a belief in the afterlife, and was concerned that they should "belong to each other" for eternity. The passage in the Gospel of John referred to in Emma's letter says "Love one another" (13:34), then describes Jesus  saying "I am the way, the truth and the life: no man cometh unto the Father, but by me" (14:6). Desmond and Moore note that the section continues: "Whoever does not abide in me is thrown away like a branch and withers; such branches are gathered, thrown into the fire and burned" (15:6). As disbelief later gradually crept over Darwin, he could "hardly see how anyone ought to wish Christianity to be true; for if so the plain language of the text seems to show that the men who do not believe, and this would include my Father, Brother and almost all my best friends, will be everlastingly punished. And this is a damnable doctrine."
Following their marriage in January 1839, they shared discussions about Christianity for many years. They socialised with the Unitarian clergymen James Martineau and John James Tayler, and read their works as well as those of other Unitarian and liberal Anglican authors such as Francis William Newman whose Phases of faith described a spiritual journey from Calvinism to theism, all part of widespread and heated debate on the authority of Anglicanism. In Downe Emma attended the Anglican village church, but as a Unitarian had the family turn round in silence when the Trinitarian Nicene Creed was recited.
Soon after their marriage, Emma wrote to Charles "while you are acting conscientiously & sincerely wishing, & trying to learn the truth, you cannot be wrong", and although concerned at the threat to faith of the "habit in scientific pursuits of believing nothing till it is proved", her hope that he did not "consider his opinion as formed" proved correct. Methodical conscientious doubt as a state of inquiry rather than disbelief made him open to nature and revelation, and they remained open with each other.']
reference_answer:
Charles Darwin's views on religion evolved significantly over time, particularly influenced by his marriage to Emma. Initially, Darwin was already skeptical about religious doctrines before he proposed to Emma in November 1838. He openly discussed his ideas on the transmutation of species with her and expressed concerns about how their differing beliefs might affect their relationship.

Emma, who held Unitarian beliefs emphasizing inner feeling over strict adherence to doctrine, valued open communication and honesty regarding personal beliefs. Despite her fears that differences in religious views could create a "painful void" between them, she encouraged Darwin to share his thoughts openly. This mutual openness was crucial for maintaining their bond despite differing perspectives.

After their marriage in January 1839, Darwin and Emma continued to engage in discussions about Christianity and religion more broadly. They socialized with Unitarian clergymen like James Martineau and John James Tayler, and read works by other liberal thinkers, which contributed to a rich environment of debate and exploration of religious ideas.

Emma's belief in the afterlife and her desire for them to "belong to each other" eternally influenced Darwin. Although he gradually developed agnosticism, Emma's support allowed him to maintain an open-minded approach to both nature and revelation. She reassured him that as long as he was acting conscientiously and sincerely seeking truth, he could not be wrong.

Darwin's methodical doubt—approaching beliefs with inquiry rather than outright disbelief—enabled him to remain receptive to new ideas. This attitude allowed for ongoing dialogue between Darwin and Emma, where they both respected each other's perspectives while exploring their own spiritual journeys. Their relationship exemplified how open communication and mutual respect can help navigate differences in belief without diminishing the closeness of a partnership.

query: Describe the relationship between Charles Darwin and his wife Emma as depicted in cultural references, particularly focusing on the 2009 film "Creation."
reference_contexts:
['== Later life and the Darwin grounds ==

Shortly before she turned 74, her husband Charles died at 73 on 19 April 1882. Subsequently, Emma spent the summers in Down House. She bought a large house called The Grove on Huntingdon Road in Cambridge, and lived there during the winters. Emma Darwin died in 1896. Her son Francis had a house, which he named Wychfield, built in the grounds of The Grove. He lived there during most winters, spending summers in Gloucestershire. Emma's son Horace also had a house built in the grounds, and named it The Orchard.
The Grove is now the central building of Fitzwilliam College, and provides common room facilities for graduates, Fellows and senior members. In January 2009, Cambridge City Council gave the College planning permission to demolish its gatehouse, Grove Lodge, which now forms part of Murray Edwards College. After local residents and academics expressed concern and there was a campaign against the demolition, the college council decided to reconsider possible alternative uses; their decision at the end of September 2009 was to keep and refurbish Grove Lodge. Architects, consultants and builders were appointed for conversion work, which when completed in September 2011 provided five new studies for Fellows.


== Children ==

The Darwins (after Charles' death in 1882, Emma and Francis) also brought up Francis' son Bernard Darwin (1876-1961) after the death of Bernard's mother a few days after he was born.


== Cultural references ==
In 2001 a biography of Emma was published written by Edna Healey, though it has been criticised for attempting to give credit to Emma for her husband's ideas, whereas other historians agree she had little, if any, scientific input.
In 2008 Mrs Charles Darwin's Recipe Book was published, with profits going to the Darwin Correspondence Project at Cambridge University.
The 2009 film Creation focuses in part on the relationship between Charles and Emma. Emma was played by Jennifer Connelly.
A boarding house at Shrewsbury School is named in her honour.


== Darwins buried at Downe ==
Eight members of the Darwin family are buried at St Mary's Church, Downe. Darwins buried at Downe include: Bernard Darwin and his wife Elinor Monsell, who taught her husband's cousin Gwen (Darwin) Raverat, engraver and author of Period Piece; Charles Waring Darwin; Elizabeth Darwin, "Aunt Bessy"; Emma Darwin, Charles Darwin's wife; Erasmus Alvey Darwin; Mary Eleanor Darwin; Henrietta Etty Darwin, later Litchfield, "Aunt Etty". Emma Darwin's sister Elizabeth Wedgwood and Aunt Sarah Wedgwood are also buried together at St Mary's.


== See also ==
Social history of the piano
Emma Darwin (novelist)
List of coupled cousins
Darwin–Wedgwood family
Emma Darwin: A Century of Family Letters


== Notes ==


== References ==
Browne, E. Janet (1995), Charles Darwin: vol. 1 Voyaging, London: Jonathan Cape, ISBN 1-84413-314-1
Browne, E. Janet (2002), Charles Darwin: vol. 2 The Power of Place, London: Jonathan Cape, ISBN 0-7126-6837-3
Darwin, Charles (1837–1838), Notebook B: [Transmutation of species], Darwin Online, CUL-DAR121, retrieved 20 December 2008
Darwin, Charles (1838), Notebook C: [Transmutation of species], Darwin Online
Darwin, Charles (1887), Darwin, Francis (ed.), The life and letters of Charles Darwin, including an autobiographical chapter, London: John Murray, retrieved 4 November 2008
Darwin, Charles (1958), Barlow, Nora (ed.), The Autobiography of Charles Darwin 1809–1882. With the original omissions restored. Edited and with appendix and notes by his granddaughter Nora Barlow, London: Collins, retrieved 4 November 2008
Desmond, Adrian; Moore, James (1991), Darwin, London: Michael Joseph, Penguin Group, ISBN 0-7181-3430-3
Freeman, R. B. (1984), . Darwin Pedigrees, London: printed for the author, retrieved 15 September 2009
Freeman, R. B. (2007), Charles Darwin: A companion (2d online ed.), The Complete Works of Charles Darwin Online, retrieved 18 June 2008
Litchfield, Henrietta Emma (1904), Emma Darwin, wife of Charles Darwin. A century of family letters, London: John Murray, retrieved 18 February 2013']
reference_answer:
In the cultural reference provided, specifically the 2009 film "Creation," the relationship between Charles Darwin and his wife Emma is portrayed with a focus on their personal dynamics during a significant period of Charles's life. The film highlights the emotional and intellectual partnership between them, particularly as Charles grapples with the development and implications of his theory of evolution by natural selection.

Emma Darwin, played by Jennifer Connelly in the film, is depicted as a supportive yet complex figure in Charles's life. She provides him with both emotional support and critical feedback on his work. The film explores their relationship against the backdrop of Charles's scientific endeavors and personal struggles, including the death of their daughter Annie, which deeply affects both Charles and Emma.

"Creation" delves into how Emma influences Charles's thinking and writing process, suggesting that her insights and perspectives contribute to his ability to articulate his groundbreaking ideas. The film portrays a nuanced relationship where Emma is not just a passive supporter but an active participant in the intellectual journey of one of history's most influential scientists.

Overall, "Creation" presents their relationship as one marked by mutual respect, deep emotional connection, and significant influence on each other's lives and work.

Darwins buried at Downe include: Bernard Darwin and his wife Elinor Monsell, who taught her husband's cousin Gwen (Darwin) Raverat, engraver and author of Period Piece; Charles Waring Darwin; Elizabeth Darwin, "Aunt Bessy"; Emma Darwin, Charles Darwin's wife; Erasmus Alvey Darwin; Mary Eleanor Darwin; Henrietta Etty Darwin, later Litchfield, "Aunt Etty". Emma Darwin's sister Elizabeth Wedgwood and Aunt Sarah Wedgwood are also buried together at St Mary's.

Eight members of the Darwin family are buried at St. Mary's Church in Downe. Two individuals from this list include:

1. Emma Darwin, who was Charles Darwin's wife.
2. Henrietta Etty Darwin, later known as Litchfield and referred to as "Aunt Etty."

These individuals are part of a larger group that includes other family members such as Bernard Darwin, his wife Elinor Monsell, Charles Waring Darwin, Elizabeth Darwin ("Aunt Bessy"), Erasmus Alvey Darwin, Mary Eleanor Darwin, and Emma Darwin's sister Elizabeth Wedgwood along with Aunt Sarah Wedgwood.

reference_answer:
The funds administered by the Geological Society—Lyell Fund, Murchison Fund, Wollaston Fund, and William Smith Fund—are likely named after prominent figures in geology. This naming convention suggests that these funds are dedicated to supporting activities or initiatives aligned with the legacy and contributions of these individuals to the field of geology.

1. **Lyell Fund**: Named after Charles Lyell, a key figure in establishing modern geology through his principles of uniformitarianism. The fund likely supports research or projects that advance geological understanding in line with Lyell's scientific approach.

2. **Murchison Fund**: Named after Roderick Murchison, known for his work on the Silurian system and contributions to stratigraphy. This fund might support studies related to stratigraphy, paleontology, or other areas where Murchison made significant impacts.

3. **Wollaston Fund**: Named after William Hyde Wollaston, who contributed to mineralogy and geology through discoveries like the mineral wollastonite. The fund could be aimed at supporting research in mineralogy or honoring innovative contributions to geological sciences.

4. **William Smith Fund**: Named after William Smith, often called the "Father of English Geology," known for creating the first nationwide geological map. This fund likely supports mapping projects, educational initiatives, or other activities that promote geological exploration and understanding.

Overall, these funds reflect the Society's mission to advance geological science by honoring past contributions and supporting ongoing research and education in areas significant to these historical figures.

The book "Whatever is Under the Earth: The Geological Society of London 1807 to 2007," authored by G.L. Herries Davies, serves as a comprehensive historical account of the Geological Society of London over two centuries. Published in 2007, it marks the bicentennial of the Society's founding and provides an extensive overview of its development, achievements, and contributions to geology.

The book contributes to our understanding of the Society's history by detailing its origins, growth, and evolution from a small group of enthusiasts into one of the world's leading geological organizations. It highlights key events, milestones, and figures that have shaped the Society over time, offering insights into how it has influenced both national and international geology.

In terms of impact, the book examines the Society's role in advancing geological science through its various activities, including the awarding of medals such as the Wollaston Medal, Murchison Medal, and Lyell Medal. These awards recognize significant contributions to geology, reflecting the Society's commitment to excellence and innovation in the field.

Additionally, the book discusses the funds administered by the Society, like the Lyell Fund, Murchison Fund, and William Smith Fund, which support research and exploration efforts. This underscores the Society's ongoing dedication to fostering scientific inquiry and discovery.

Overall, "Whatever is Under the Earth" provides a detailed narrative of the Geological Society of London's enduring legacy and its pivotal role in shaping geological science from 1807 to 2007.

query: How did John Stevens Henslow's early education and career choices reflect his passion for natural history, and what positions did he hold at Cambridge University?
reference_contexts:
['John Stevens Henslow (6 February 1796 – 16 May 1861) was an English Anglican priest, botanist and geologist. He is best remembered as friend and mentor to Charles Darwin.


== Early life ==
Henslow was born at Rochester, Kent, the son of a solicitor John Prentis Henslow, who was the son of John Henslow.
Henslow was educated at St. John's College, Cambridge where he graduated as 16th wrangler in 1818, the year in which Adam Sedgwick became Woodwardian Professor of Geology.


== Early career ==
Henslow graduated in 1818. He already had a passion for natural history from his childhood, which largely influenced his career, and he accompanied Sedgwick in 1819 on a tour in the Isle of Wight where he learned his first lessons in geology. He also studied chemistry under Professor James Cumming and mineralogy under Edward Daniel Clarke. In the autumn of 1819 he made valuable observations on the geology of the Isle of Man (Trans. Geol. Soc., 1821) and in 1820 and 1821 he investigated the geology of parts of Anglesey, the results being printed in the first volume of the Transactions of the Cambridge Philosophical Society (1822). The Philosophical Society was founded in November 1819 by a group at Cambridge with Professors Farish, Lee, and Sedgwick and Henslow (at that time not yet a professor). The idea and initial impetus for the society originated from Sedgwick and Henslow.
Meanwhile, Henslow had studied mineralogy with considerable zeal, so that on the death of Clarke he was in 1822 appointed professor of mineralogy in the University of Cambridge. Two years later he took holy orders. Botany, however, had claimed much of his attention, and to this science he became more and more attached, so that he gladly resigned the chair of mineralogy in 1827, two years after becoming professor of botany. As a teacher both in the classroom and in the field he was eminently successful. He was a correspondent of John James Audubon who in 1829 named Henslow's sparrow (Centronyx henslowii) after him.
From 1821 Henslow had begun organising a herbarium of British flora, supplementing his own collecting with a network which expanded over time to include his friends and family, and the botanists William Jackson Hooker and John Hutton Balfour, as well as about 30 of his students. As a mineralogist he had used Haüy's laws of crystallography to analyse complex crystals as transformations of "the primitive form of the species" of crystal, and when he moved to botany in 1825 he sought similarly precise laws to group plant varieties into species, often including as varieties plants that respected taxonomists had ranked as separate species. He followed the understanding of the time that species were fixed as created but could vary within limits, and hoped to analyse these limits of variation. By a method he called "collation", Henslow prepared sheets with several plant specimens, each labelled with the collector, date and place of collection, comparing the specimens to show the variation within the species. His A Catalogue of British Plants was first published in October 1829, and became a set book for his lecture course.
Henslow is remembered as friend and mentor to his pupil Charles Darwin, and for inspiring him with a passion for natural history. The two met in 1828. Earlier that year, Darwin joined the course and along with other students helped to collect plants of Cambridgeshire. Henslow became his tutor, and it was not long before he marked out Darwin as a promising student. In 1830 Henslow experimented on varying the conditions of garden grown wild plants to produce various forms of the plant. In 1835 Henslow published Principles of Descriptive and Physiological Botany as a textbook based on this lecture course.
In the summer of 1831 Henslow was offered a place as naturalist to sail aboard the survey ship HMS Beagle on a two-year voyage to survey South America, but his wife dissuaded him from accepting. Seeing a perfect opportunity for his protégé, Henslow wrote to the ship's captain Robert Fitzroy telling him that Darwin was the ideal man to join the expedition team. During the voyage, Darwin corresponded with Henslow, and collected plants with him in mind. In particular, when first arriving at the Galápagos Islands Darwin noted "I certainly recognize S America in Ornithology, would a botanist?", and went on to collect plant specimens carefully labelled by island and date. He also labelled the mockingbirds he caught, and initially thought these were varieties but while arranging these bird specimens on the last lap of the voyage he began wondering if they could be species, a possibility which would "undermine the stability of Species". Henslow's teaching continued to influence Darwin's work on evolution.
Besides Darwin, other famous students of Henslow included Miles Joseph Berkeley, Cardale Babington, Leonard Jenyns, Richard Thomas Lowe and William Hallowes Miller.']
reference_answer:
John Stevens Henslow's early education and career choices were deeply influenced by his passion for natural history. Educated at St. John's College, Cambridge, where he graduated as the 16th wrangler in 1818, Henslow demonstrated an early interest in scientific disciplines. His passion was further nurtured through various educational experiences:

1. **Geology and Mineralogy**: After graduating, Henslow accompanied Adam Sedgwick on a tour of the Isle of Wight in 1819 to learn geology. He also studied chemistry under Professor James Cumming and mineralogy under Edward Daniel Clarke.

2. **Fieldwork and Research**: Henslow conducted significant geological research on the Isle of Man (published in 1821) and parts of Anglesey, contributing valuable observations to the field.

3. **Academic Positions at Cambridge**:
   - In 1822, following Edward Daniel Clarke's death, Henslow was appointed as the professor of mineralogy at the University of Cambridge.
   - Two years later, he took holy orders but continued his academic pursuits in natural history.
   - By 1827, Henslow had shifted his focus to botany and resigned from the chair of mineralogy. He became a professor of botany, where he excelled as both a classroom teacher and field instructor.

4. **Botanical Contributions**: Henslow organized a herbarium of British flora and sought precise laws for grouping plant varieties into species. His work in this area culminated in the publication of "A Catalogue of British Plants" in 1829, which became essential reading for his lecture course.

Through these educational pursuits and academic positions at Cambridge University—professor of mineralogy (1822-1827) and professor of botany (from 1827)—Henslow's career choices clearly reflected his enduring passion for natural history. His influence extended to mentoring notable students, including Charles Darwin, further underscoring his impact on the field.

query: Name two publications by John Stevens Henslow that were reissued by Cambridge University Press in 2009, along with their respective ISBN numbers.
reference_contexts:
['== Family ==
Henslow married Harriet Jenyns (1797–1857), daughter of George Leonard Jenyns and sister of Leonard Jenyns on 16 December 1823. Their eldest daughter Frances Harriet married Joseph Dalton Hooker, and their youngest daughter, Anne, became a botanical artist. Their sons included George Henslow (1835–1925), who became the Royal Horticultural Society's Professor of Botany and the first President of the Churchmen's Union for the Advancement of Liberal Religious Thought.

Two publications by John Stevens Henslow that were reissued by Cambridge University Press in 2009 are:

1. "A Syllabus of a Course of Lectures on Mineralogy" (1823), with the ISBN number 978-1-108-00201-1.
2. "The Principles of Descriptive and Physiological Botany" (1835), with the ISBN number 978-1-108-00186-1.

These reissues are part of a series that includes several other works by Henslow, reflecting his contributions to botany and mineralogy.

query: Describe the purpose of the Sedgwick Prize established by A. A. Van Sittart in 1865, including details about its frequency and significance.
reference_contexts:
['== Legacy ==

The Sedgwick Club, the oldest student-run geological society in the world, was set up in honour of him in 1880.
On the death of Sedgwick it was decided that his memorial should take the form of a new and larger museum. There was brief, later discarded, talk of opening a Sedgwick youth summer programme. Hitherto the geological collections had been placed in the Woodwardian Museum in Cockerell's Building. Through the energy of Professor T. McK. Hughes (successor to Sedgwick) the new building, termed the Sedgwick Museum, was completed and opened in 1903.
In 1865, the University of Cambridge received from A. A. Van Sittart the sum of 500 pounds sterling "for the purpose of encouraging the study of geology among the resident members of the university, and in honour of the Rev. Adam Sedgwick". Thus was founded the Sedgwick Prize to be given every third year for the best essay on some geological subject. The first Sedgwick Prize was awarded in 1873 and has continued into the 21st century.
To celebrate the bicentenary of Sedgwick's birth a geological trail was created near Dent, the village where he was born and developed his passion for geology (amongst other things). The Sedgwick Trail follows the River Clough, highlighting rock features and exploring the Dent Fault.
Mount Sedgwick in British Columbia, Canada, was officially named after him in 1951.


== Notes ==


== References ==
Chisholm, Hugh, ed. (1911). "Sedgwick, Adam" . Encyclopædia Britannica. Vol. 24 (11th ed.). Cambridge University Press. pp. 557–558.
J.W. Clark and T.M. Hughes, The Life and Letters of the Reverend Adam Sedgwick, Cambridge University Press, 1890, vols. 1–2. (Reissued by Cambridge University Press, 2010. ISBN 978-1-108-01831-9)
Dictionary of Scientific Biography, Charles Scribner's Sons: 1970–1990; vol. 12, pp. 275–279.
A Biographical Dictionary of Scientists, Williams, T. I., Ed., Wiley, 1969, pp. 467–468.
Isaac Asimov, I. Asimov's Biographical Encyclopedia of Science and Technology (2nd Ed.), Doubleday: 1982, p. 299.
Quart. J. Geol. Soc., 1873, 29, pp. xxx–xxxix.
Bonney, Thomas George (1889). "Sedgwick, Adam" . In Stephen, Leslie (ed.). Dictionary of National Biography. Vol. 17. London: Smith, Elder & Co. pp. 179–182.
"Adam Sedgwick – Geologist and Dalesman" Colin Speakman Broad Oak Press 1982.
"Adam Sedgwick's Dent"  A facsimile reprint of 'A Memorial by the Trustees of Cowgill Chapel (1868) and 'Supplement to the Memorial (1870) by Adam Sedgwick with introduction by David Boulton Hollett, Sedbergh and David Boulton Dent 1984.
"A Discourse on the Studies of the University" Adam Sedgwick The Victorian Library, Leicester University Press 1969
Browne, E. Janet (1995), Charles Darwin: vol. 1 Voyaging, London: Jonathan Cape, ISBN 1-84413-314-1
Herbert, Sandra (1991), "Charles Darwin as a prospective geological author", British Journal for the History of Science, vol. 24, no. 2, pp. 159–192, doi:10.1017/s0007087400027060, S2CID 143748414, archived from the original on 8 February 2009, retrieved 24 January 2009
Secord, James A. (2000), Victorian Sensation: the extraordinary publication, reception, and secret authorship of Vestiges of the natural history of creation, Chicago: University of Chicago Press, ISBN 0-226-74411-6


== External links ==

Sedgwick Museum, Cambridge

The life and letters of the Reverend Adam Sedgwick Vol.1 by J.W.Clark, 1890
The life and letters of the Reverend Adam Sedgwick Vol.2 by J.W.Clark, 1890
Obituary in: "Obituary" . Popular Science Monthly. Vol. 2. April 1873.']
reference_answer:
The Sedgwick Prize was established by A. A. Van Sittart in 1865 with the specific purpose of encouraging the study of geology among resident members of the University of Cambridge. This initiative was made in honor of the Reverend Adam Sedgwick, a prominent figure in the field of geology. The prize is awarded every third year for the best essay on some geological subject, highlighting its role as an academic incentive and recognition within the university's geological community.

The significance of the Sedgwick Prize lies not only in its encouragement of scholarly work but also in its longevity and prestige. Since its inception, it has continued to be awarded into the 21st century, marking it as a longstanding tradition that underscores the importance of geology at Cambridge University. The first award was given in 1873, further cementing its place as an enduring academic accolade.

Overall, the Sedgwick Prize serves both as a tribute to Adam Sedgwick's contributions to geology and as a means to foster ongoing research and excellence within the field among students at the University of Cambridge.

Mount Sedgwick in British Columbia, Canada, holds significance as a geographical feature named in honor of Adam Sedgwick, a prominent geologist. The mountain was officially named after him in 1951 to recognize his contributions to the field of geology and his influence on geological studies.

Adam Sedgwick was an influential figure in the development of geology during the 19th century. He played a crucial role in advancing geological understanding through his work, teachings, and mentorship. His legacy includes founding the Sedgwick Club, which is the oldest student-run geological society in the world, established in 1880 to honor him.

Additionally, Sedgwick's impact extended beyond academia; he inspired various memorials and initiatives that continue to celebrate his contributions. For instance, the Sedgwick Museum at the University of Cambridge was completed in 1903 as a memorial to him, housing geological collections previously placed in the Woodwardian Museum. Furthermore, the Sedgwick Prize, established in 1865 with funds from A.A. Van Sittart, is awarded every third year for outstanding essays on geological subjects.

The naming of Mount Sedgwick serves as a lasting tribute to his legacy and influence in geology, commemorating his life's work and passion for understanding the Earth's geological features.

query: What concerns did Darwin express about sharing his journal with others, and how did his family respond to these concerns?
reference_contexts:
['=== Darwin's diary / journal ===
On board the ship, Darwin began a day-to-day record of activities in the form of a diary, which he commonly called "my Journal". Darwin wrote entries, in ink, while on the ship or when staying for a period in a house on shore. When travelling on land, he left the manuscript on the ship, and made pencil notes in pocket books to record details of his excursions along with his field notes on geology and natural history. He then wrote up his diary entries from these notes or from memory, sometimes several weeks after the event.
Pages 1 and 2, dated 16 December 1831, outline events from Darwin arriving home on 29 August to his arrival at Devonport on 24 October. From page 3 onwards he adopts a consistent layout, with month, the year and place in a heading at the top, page number in a top corner, and the day of the month in the margin at each entry. After delays and false starts due to weather, they set off on 27 December. Darwin suffered seasickness, and his entry for that date starts "I am now on the 5th of Jan.y writing the memoranda of my misery for the last week".
In April, a month after reaching South America, he wrote to his sister Caroline that he was struggling to write letters, partly due to "writing everything in my journal". A few weeks later at Botafogo in Rio de Janeiro, tired and short of time, he sent her "in a packet, my commonplace Journal.— I have taken a fit of disgust with it & want to get it out of my sight, any of you that like may read it.— a great deal is absolutely childish: Remember however this, that it is written solely to make me remember this voyage, & that it is not a record of facts but of my thoughts". He invited criticisms. In reply, his sister Catherine praised his "interesting and entertaining" descriptions,  "Susan read the Journal aloud to Papa, who was interested, and liked it very much". His Wedgwood relatives had asked to see it at Maer Hall. Darwin left that "entirely in your hands.— I suspect the first part is abominaly childish, if so do not send it to Maer.— Also, do not send it by the Coach, (it may appear ridiculous to you) but I would as soon loose a piece of my memory as it.— I feel it is of such consequence to my preserving a just recollection of the different places we visit."
By 14 July 1833 Darwin had sent more of his diary. On 28 October Caroline gave the requested critical assessment – in the first part Darwin had "probably from reading so much of Humboldt, got his phraseology & occasionly made use of the kind of flowery french expressions which he uses, instead of your own simple straight forward & far more agreeable style. I have no doubt you have without perceiving it got to embody your ideas in his poetical language & from his being a foreigner it does not sound unnatural in him". However, "the greatest part I liked exceedingly & could find no fault". In July 1834, Darwin agreed that these points were "perfectly just", and continued to update his diary carefully.
As Beagle headed homewards in April 1836,  Darwin told Caroline that FitzRoy too was busy with writing "the account of the Voyage". This "Book" might be "rather diffuse", but otherwise good: "his style is very simple & excellent. He has proposed to me, to join him in publishing the account, that is, for him to have the disposal & arranging of my journal & to mingle it with his own. Of course I have said I am perfectly willing, if he wants materials; or thinks the chit-chat details of my journal are any ways worth publishing. He has read over the part, I have on board, & likes it." Darwin asked his family about this idea, but would be aware the custom of the Navy was that the captain had a right to first use of papers.']
reference_answer:
Charles Darwin expressed several concerns regarding sharing his journal with others. Firstly, he was worried that parts of his journal might be perceived as "childish" or overly influenced by the style of Alexander von Humboldt, which included flowery French expressions. He feared this could affect how his work was received and valued. Additionally, Darwin was concerned about preserving the accuracy of his memories regarding the places they visited during the voyage.

Despite these concerns, Darwin's family responded positively to his journal. His sister Catherine found his descriptions "interesting and entertaining," while Susan read it aloud to their father, who also enjoyed it. The Wedgwood relatives expressed interest in seeing the journal at Maer Hall, but Darwin left the decision of sharing it entirely in their hands, particularly advising against sending parts he deemed unsuitable.

Caroline provided a critical assessment, noting that Darwin had adopted Humboldt's phraseology and suggesting he return to his simpler style. However, she also praised most of the content as excellent. Overall, Darwin's family seemed supportive and appreciative of his work, encouraging him to continue updating his diary carefully.

query: Describe the arrangement between Darwin and Captain FitzRoy regarding the publication of their voyage accounts. How did naval customs influence this agreement?
reference_contexts:
['=== Darwin's diary / journal ===
On board the ship, Darwin began a day-to-day record of activities in the form of a diary, which he commonly called "my Journal". Darwin wrote entries, in ink, while on the ship or when staying for a period in a house on shore. When travelling on land, he left the manuscript on the ship, and made pencil notes in pocket books to record details of his excursions along with his field notes on geology and natural history. He then wrote up his diary entries from these notes or from memory, sometimes several weeks after the event.
Pages 1 and 2, dated 16 December 1831, outline events from Darwin arriving home on 29 August to his arrival at Devonport on 24 October. From page 3 onwards he adopts a consistent layout, with month, the year and place in a heading at the top, page number in a top corner, and the day of the month in the margin at each entry. After delays and false starts due to weather, they set off on 27 December. Darwin suffered seasickness, and his entry for that date starts "I am now on the 5th of Jan.y writing the memoranda of my misery for the last week".
In April, a month after reaching South America, he wrote to his sister Caroline that he was struggling to write letters, partly due to "writing everything in my journal". A few weeks later at Botafogo in Rio de Janeiro, tired and short of time, he sent her "in a packet, my commonplace Journal.— I have taken a fit of disgust with it & want to get it out of my sight, any of you that like may read it.— a great deal is absolutely childish: Remember however this, that it is written solely to make me remember this voyage, & that it is not a record of facts but of my thoughts". He invited criticisms. In reply, his sister Catherine praised his "interesting and entertaining" descriptions,  "Susan read the Journal aloud to Papa, who was interested, and liked it very much". His Wedgwood relatives had asked to see it at Maer Hall. Darwin left that "entirely in your hands.— I suspect the first part is abominaly childish, if so do not send it to Maer.— Also, do not send it by the Coach, (it may appear ridiculous to you) but I would as soon loose a piece of my memory as it.— I feel it is of such consequence to my preserving a just recollection of the different places we visit."
By 14 July 1833 Darwin had sent more of his diary. On 28 October Caroline gave the requested critical assessment – in the first part Darwin had "probably from reading so much of Humboldt, got his phraseology & occasionly made use of the kind of flowery french expressions which he uses, instead of your own simple straight forward & far more agreeable style. I have no doubt you have without perceiving it got to embody your ideas in his poetical language & from his being a foreigner it does not sound unnatural in him". However, "the greatest part I liked exceedingly & could find no fault". In July 1834, Darwin agreed that these points were "perfectly just", and continued to update his diary carefully.
As Beagle headed homewards in April 1836,  Darwin told Caroline that FitzRoy too was busy with writing "the account of the Voyage". This "Book" might be "rather diffuse", but otherwise good: "his style is very simple & excellent. He has proposed to me, to join him in publishing the account, that is, for him to have the disposal & arranging of my journal & to mingle it with his own. Of course I have said I am perfectly willing, if he wants materials; or thinks the chit-chat details of my journal are any ways worth publishing. He has read over the part, I have on board, & likes it." Darwin asked his family about this idea, but would be aware the custom of the Navy was that the captain had a right to first use of papers.']
reference_answer:
The arrangement between Charles Darwin and Captain Robert FitzRoy concerning the publication of their voyage accounts involved a collaborative effort where FitzRoy proposed that they publish an account together. In this collaboration, FitzRoy would have control over how to arrange and incorporate Darwin's journal entries into the final published work. Darwin agreed to this proposal, indicating his willingness to contribute materials from his journal if FitzRoy deemed them valuable for publication.

Naval customs played a significant role in shaping this agreement. According to these customs, the captain of a naval expedition had the right to first use any papers or documents produced during the voyage. This meant that FitzRoy, as the captain of HMS Beagle, held primary rights over the materials collected and documented by Darwin during their journey. Consequently, Darwin's journal entries could be used at FitzRoy's discretion for his account of the voyage, reflecting the hierarchical structure and customary practices within naval expeditions of that time. This arrangement ensured that FitzRoy had editorial control while allowing Darwin to contribute to a broader narrative about their scientific discoveries and experiences.

query: Who were the individuals that Darwin consulted about publishing his journal, and what was their general opinion on how it should be published?
reference_contexts: ['=== Journal and remarks ===\nSoon after Darwin\'s return, he was at a party hosted by Fanny and Hensleigh Wedgwood for their relatives on 4 December 1836. They agreed to review his journal. The physician and travel writer Henry Holland looked at some pages and "thought that it would not be worth while to publish it alone, as it would be partly going over the same ground with the Captain", leaving Darwin "more perplexed" but "becoming rather inclined to the plan of mixing up long passages with Capt Fitzroy." He would "go on with the geology and let the journal take care of itself", but Emma Wedgwood did not think Holland "any judge as to what is amusing or interesting", and like Catherine thought it should be published by itself, not "mixed up with Capt. FitzRoy\'s". Fanny and Hensleigh found the "Journal so interesting, that it is quite difficult to stop to criticize". Though "not in general a good reader of travels", he "found no part of yours tedious." They had "read a great deal of it aloud too" as a more severe test, and concluded it had "more variety and a greater number of interesting portions" than other travel books, "the less it is mixed up with the Captains the better." \nAfter advice from Broderip, FitzRoy wrote on 30 December that "One volume might be for King—another for you—and a third for me. The profits if any, to be divided into three equal portions—What think you of such a plan?" Darwin agreed, and began work on his volume. In March he told Fox "I am now hard at work and give up every thing else for it. Our plan is as follows.— Capt. FitzRoy writes two volumes, out of the materials collected during both the last voyage under Capt. King to T. del Fuego and during our circumnavigation.— I am to have the third volume, in which I intend giving a kind of journal of a naturalist, not following however always the order of time, but rather the order of position.— The habits of animals will occupy a large portion, sketches of the geology, the appearance of the country, and personal details will make the hodge-podge complete.— Afterwards I shall write an account of the geology in detail, and draw up some Zoological papers.— So that I have plenty of work, for the next year or two, and till that is finished I will have no holidays."']
reference_answer:
Charles Darwin consulted several individuals regarding the publication of his journal. These included:

1. **Henry Holland**: A physician and travel writer who reviewed some pages of Darwin's journal. He suggested that it might not be worthwhile to publish the journal alone, as it would overlap with Captain FitzRoy's accounts. This left Darwin more perplexed.

2. **Emma Wedgwood**: She disagreed with Holland’s assessment, stating he was not a good judge of what is amusing or interesting. Emma supported the idea of publishing the journal by itself rather than mixing it with Captain FitzRoy's work.

3. **Catherine (likely Catherine Darwin)**: Like Emma, she believed that the journal should be published separately and not mixed with Captain FitzRoy’s accounts.

4. **Fanny Wedgwood**: She found the journal very interesting and thought it was difficult to criticize. Fanny agreed with her brother Hensleigh that the journal had more variety and interesting portions than other travel books, suggesting it would be better off not being mixed with Captain FitzRoy's writings.

5. **Hensleigh Wedgwood**: He shared Fanny’s view on the journal's interest and variety, also supporting its separate publication from Captain FitzRoy's accounts.

Overall, while Henry Holland suggested combining Darwin's work with Captain FitzRoy's, Emma Wedgwood, Catherine, Fanny, and Hensleigh Wedgwood all favored publishing Darwin's journal independently.

query: Describe the plan proposed by FitzRoy for dividing the work into volumes and how Darwin intended to structure his own volume.

They agreed to review his journal. The physician and travel writer Henry Holland looked at some pages and "thought that it would not be worth while to publish it alone, as it would be partly going over the same ground with the Captain", leaving Darwin "more perplexed" but "becoming rather inclined to the plan of mixing up long passages with Capt Fitzroy." Though "not in general a good reader of travels", he "found no part of yours tedious." They had "read a great deal of it aloud too" as a more severe test, and concluded it had "more variety and a greater number of interesting portions" than other travel books, "the less it is mixed up with the Captains the better." \nAfter advice from Broderip, FitzRoy wrote on 30 December that "One volume might be for King—another for you—and a third for me. King to T. del Fuego and during our circumnavigation.— I am to have the third volume, in which I intend giving a kind of journal of a naturalist, not following however always the order of time, but rather the order of position.— The habits of animals will occupy a large portion, sketches of the geology, the appearance of the country, and personal details will make the hodge-podge complete.— Afterwards I shall write an account of the geology in detail, and draw up some Zoological papers.— So that I have plenty of work, for the next year or two, and till that is finished I will have no holidays."']
reference_answer:
FitzRoy proposed a collaborative plan for publishing their experiences from the voyage. The idea was to divide the content into three separate volumes, each authored individually but based on shared materials collected during the voyages under Captain King and FitzRoy's circumnavigation. Specifically:

1. **Volume Division**: 
   - One volume would be dedicated to King.
   - Another volume would be written by FitzRoy himself.
   - The third volume was assigned to Darwin.

2. **Profit Sharing**:
   - Any profits from the publication of these volumes were to be divided equally among the three contributors: King, FitzRoy, and Darwin.

Darwin's approach for his own volume involved a unique structure:

1. **Content Focus**: 
   - Darwin intended to write as if he were keeping a journal of a naturalist.
   
2. **Structure**:
   - Instead of following a strict chronological order, Darwin planned to organize the content based on geographical position or thematic relevance.
   
3. **Key Elements**:
   - A significant portion would be dedicated to the habits of animals.
   - He also intended to include sketches of geology and descriptions of the appearance of various countries visited during the voyage.
   - Personal details and experiences would be interspersed throughout, creating a comprehensive narrative.

4. **Future Work**:
   - After completing this volume, Darwin planned to write in more detail about the geological aspects and prepare some zoological papers, indicating his commitment to extensive work on these subjects for the following year or two.

This plan reflects both FitzRoy's collaborative spirit and Darwin's dedication to thoroughly documenting their scientific observations.

query: What specific aspects of natural history did Darwin plan to focus on in his volume, and what additional works did he intend to produce after completing this project?
reference_contexts: ['=== Journal and remarks ===\nSoon after Darwin\'s return, he was at a party hosted by Fanny and Hensleigh Wedgwood for their relatives on 4 December 1836. They agreed to review his journal. The physician and travel writer Henry Holland looked at some pages and "thought that it would not be worth while to publish it alone, as it would be partly going over the same ground with the Captain", leaving Darwin "more perplexed" but "becoming rather inclined to the plan of mixing up long passages with Capt Fitzroy." reference_answer:
In his planned volume, Charles Darwin intended to focus on several specific aspects of natural history. He aimed to provide a "kind of journal of a naturalist," which would not strictly follow the chronological order but rather be organized by geographical position. Key elements he planned to include were:

1. **Habits of Animals**: A significant portion of his volume was dedicated to exploring and documenting animal behaviors.
2. **Geology**: He intended to incorporate sketches and observations related to geology, providing insights into the geological features encountered during his travels.
3. **Appearance of the Country**: Descriptions of the landscapes and physical characteristics of various regions were also planned.
4. **Personal Details**: Personal anecdotes and experiences would be included to enrich the narrative.

After completing this volume, Darwin had additional projects in mind:

1. **Detailed Account of Geology**: He planned to write a more comprehensive work focusing specifically on geological observations.
2. **Zoological Papers**: Darwin intended to prepare detailed papers on zoological subjects, likely expanding upon the animal habits and species he documented during his travels.

These plans indicate that Darwin was preparing for an extensive period of research and writing following the completion of his initial volume.

query: Describe the role of John Murray and Robert Taylor Pritchett in the publication history of Darwin's "Journal of Researches," particularly focusing on their contributions to the editions released in 1845 and 1890.
reference_contexts:
['=== Second edition: changing ideas on evolution ===

The second edition of 1845 incorporated extensive revisions made in the light of interpretation of the field collections and developing ideas on evolution. This edition was commissioned by the publisher John Murray, who actually paid Darwin a fee of £150 for the copyright. The full title was modified to Journal of Researches into the Natural History and Geology of the countries visited during the voyage of H.M.S. Beagle round the world.
In the first edition, Darwin remarks in regard to the similarity of Galápagos wildlife to that on the South American continent, "The circumstance would be explained, according to the views of some authors, by saying that the creative power had acted according to the same law over a wide area". (This was written in a reference to Charles Lyell's ideas of "centres of creation".) Darwin notes the gradations in size of the beaks of species of finches, suspects that species "are confined to different islands", "But there is not space in this work, to enter into this curious subject."
Later editions hint at his new ideas on evolution:

Considering the small size of these islands, we feel the more astonished at the number of their aboriginal beings, and at their confined range... within a period geologically recent the unbroken ocean was here spread out. Hence, both in space and time, we seem to be brought somewhat near to that great fact – that mystery of mysteries – the first appearance of new beings on this earth.
Speaking of the finches with their gradations in size of beaks, he writes "one might really fancy that from an original paucity of birds in this archipelago, one species had been taken and modified for different ends."
In 1890, John Murray published an illustrated edition of the book, at the suggestion of the artist Robert Taylor Pritchett, who was already known for accompanying voyages of the RYS Wanderer and Sunbeam, and producing pictures used in books on these cruises. In his foreword to this edition of Journal and Researches, Murray said that most "of the views given in this work are from sketches made on the spot by Mr. Pritchett, with Mr. Darwin's book by his side", and the illustrations had been "chosen and verified with the utmost care and pains".


== Contents – places Darwin visited ==
For readability, the chapters of the book are arranged geographically rather than in an exact chronological sequence of places Darwin visited or revisited. The main headings (and in some cases subheadings) of each chapter give a good idea of where he went, but not the exact sequence. See second voyage of HMS Beagle for a detailed synopsis of Darwin's travels. The contents list in the book also notes topics discussed in each chapter, not shown here for simplicity. Names and spellings are those used by Darwin. The list below is based on the Journal and Remarks of 1839.

Preface
Chapter I: St. Jago–Cape de Verde Islands (St. Paul's Rocks, Fernando Noronha, 20 Feb.., Bahia, or San Salvador, Brazil, 29 Feb..)
Chapter II: Rio de Janeiro
Chapter III: Maldonado
Chapter IV: Río Negro to Bahia Blanca
Chapter V: Bahía Blanca
Chapter VI: Bahia Blanca to Buenos Aires
Chapter VII: Buenos Aires to St. Fe
Chapter VIII: Banda Oriental
Chapter IX: Patagonia
Chapter X: Santa Cruz–Patagonia
Chapter XI: Tierra del Fuego
Chapter XII: The Falkland Islands
Chapter XIII: Strait of Magellan
Chapter XIV: Central Chile
Chapter XV: Chiloe and Chonos Islands
Chapter XVI: Chiloe and Concepcion
Chapter XVII: Passage of Cordillera
Chapter XVIII: Northern Chile and Peru
Chapter XIX: Galapagos Archipelago
Chapter XX: Tahiti and New Zealand
Chapter XXI: Australia (Van Diemen's Land)
Chapter XXII: Coral Formations (Keeling or Cocos Islands)
Chapter XXIII: Mauritius to England
In the second edition, the Journal of Researches of 1845, chapters VIII and IX were merged into a new chapter VIII on "Banda Oriental and Patagonia", and chapter IX now included "Santa Cruz, Patagonia and The Falkland Islands". After chapter X on Tierra del Fuego, chapter XI had the revised heading "Strait of Magellan–Climate of the Southern Coasts". The following chapters were renumbered accordingly. Chapter XIV was given the revised heading "Chiloe and Concepcion: Great Earthquake", and chapter XX had the heading "Keeling Island:–Coral Formations", with the concluding chapter XXI keeping the heading "Mauritius to England".


== Notes ==']
reference_answer:
John Murray played a significant role in the publication history of Charles Darwin's "Journal of Researches." In 1845, he commissioned the second edition of the book, which incorporated extensive revisions reflecting Darwin's developing ideas on evolution. This edition was notable for its expanded title and included insights into evolutionary theory that were not present in the first edition. For his role in commissioning this revised edition, John Murray paid Darwin a fee of £150 for the copyright.

In 1890, John Murray again contributed to the publication history by releasing an illustrated edition of "Journal of Researches." This edition was suggested by Robert Taylor Pritchett, an artist known for accompanying voyages and producing illustrations for books on these cruises. In his foreword to this edition, Murray highlighted that most views in the book were based on sketches made by Pritchett during Darwin's travels, with Darwin's original work as a reference. Murray emphasized that these illustrations had been "chosen and verified with the utmost care and pains," underscoring their authenticity and relevance.

Robert Taylor Pritchett's contribution was primarily through his artistic skills, providing visual representations of the places and subjects described in Darwin's journal. His involvement ensured that the 1890 edition offered readers a more vivid and accurate depiction of Darwin's observations during his voyage on HMS Beagle.

In summary, John Murray facilitated both the textual revisions and the enhanced visual presentation of Darwin's work through these editions, while Robert Taylor Pritchett contributed by providing detailed illustrations that enriched the reader's experience.

query: How were the chapters of Darwin's book reorganized in the second edition, specifically regarding the geographical regions covered by chapters VIII through XI? Provide details on how these changes reflect a restructuring of content.

['=== Second edition: changing ideas on evolution ===

After chapter X on Tierra del Fuego, chapter XI had the revised heading "Strait of Magellan–Climate of the Southern Coasts". The following chapters were renumbered accordingly. Chapter XIV was given the revised heading "Chiloe and Concepcion: Great Earthquake", and chapter XX had the heading "Keeling Island:–Coral Formations", with the concluding chapter XXI keeping the heading "Mauritius to England".


== Notes ==']
reference_answer:
In the second edition of Charles Darwin's "Journal of Researches" (1845), there were specific changes to the organization and headings of certain chapters, particularly those covering geographical regions from chapters VIII through XI. Here are the details on how these chapters were reorganized:

1. **Chapters VIII and IX Merged**: In the first edition, Chapter VIII was titled "Banda Oriental," and Chapter IX covered "Patagonia." In the second edition, these two chapters were merged into a single chapter VIII with the new title "Banda Oriental and Patagonia." This restructuring reflects an effort to consolidate related geographical content under one heading.

2. **Inclusion of Additional Regions**: The newly combined Chapter VIII also included information on "Santa Cruz" and "The Falkland Islands," which were originally covered in separate chapters (Chapter IX for Santa Cruz, and Chapter XII for the Falkland Islands) in the first edition. This indicates a reorganization to provide a more comprehensive overview of these interconnected regions within one chapter.

3. **Revised Heading for Chapter XI**: In the second edition, after Chapter X on "Tierra del Fuego," Chapter XI was given the revised heading "Strait of Magellan–Climate of the Southern Coasts." This change reflects an expansion or refinement in content to include additional thematic elements such as climate alongside geographical descriptions.

4. **Renumbering of Subsequent Chapters**: Due to these changes, chapters that followed were renumbered accordingly. For example, what was Chapter IX in the first edition became Chapter X in the second edition, and so on for subsequent chapters.

These modifications reflect a restructuring aimed at providing a more integrated narrative of Darwin's observations across related geographical regions, possibly to enhance coherence or thematic focus within the text.

reference_answer:
The publication edited by Nora Barlow that includes restored original omissions from Charles Darwin's autobiography is "The Autobiography of Charles Darwin 1809–1882. With the original omissions restored." This edition was published in 1958 and features appendixes and notes provided by his grand-daughter, Nora Barlow. The citation for this work can be found as follows:

- Darwin, Charles (1958), Barlow, N (ed.), *The autobiography of Charles Darwin 1809–1882. With the original omissions restored.* Edited and with appendix and notes by his grand-daughter Nora Barlow., London: Collins.

reference_answer:
"The Voyage of the Beagle" is available as a full text on the following two platforms:

1. **Project Gutenberg**: This platform offers "The Voyage of the Beagle" in various digital formats such as plain text, HTML, and ePub. A unique feature of Project Gutenberg is that it provides free access to these texts, making them widely accessible for reading on different devices without any cost.

2. **LibriVox**: On this platform, "The Voyage of the Beagle" is available in an audiobook format. LibriVox's unique offering is its collection of public domain audiobooks read by volunteers from around the world, allowing users to listen to books for free, which can be particularly beneficial for those who prefer auditory learning or have visual impairments.

These platforms cater to different preferences and needs, with Project Gutenberg focusing on text accessibility and LibriVox providing an audio experience.

query: What significant change regarding eligibility for the Copley Medal occurred in 1831?
reference_contexts:
['The Copley Medal is the most prestigious award of the Royal Society of the United Kingdom, conferred "for sustained, outstanding achievements in any field of science". The award alternates between the physical sciences or mathematics and the biological sciences. It is arguably the highest British and Commonwealth award for scientific achievement, and has often been included among the most distinguished international scientific awards.
Given annually, the medal is the oldest Royal Society medal awarded and the oldest surviving scientific award in the world, having first been given in 1731 to Stephen Gray, for "his new Electrical Experiments: – as an encouragement to him for the readiness he has always shown in obliging the Society with his discoveries and improvements in this part of Natural Knowledge". The medal is made of silver-gilt and awarded with a £25,000 prize.
It is awarded to "senior scientists" irrespective of nationality, and nominations are considered over three nomination cycles. Since 2022, scientific teams or research groups are collectively eligible to receive the medal; that year, the research team which developed the Oxford–AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine became the first collective recipient. John Theophilus Desaguliers has won the medal the most often, winning three times, in 1734, 1736 and 1741. In 1976, Dorothy Hodgkin became the first female recipient; Jocelyn Bell Burnell, in 2021, became the second.


== History ==
In 1709, Sir Godfrey Copley, the MP for Thirsk, bequeathed Abraham Hill and Hans Sloane £100 (roughly equivalent to £17,156 in 2023) to be held in trust for the Royal Society "for improving natural knowledge to be laid out in experiments or otherwise for the benefit thereof as they shall direct and appoint". After the legacy had been received the following year, the interest of £5 was duly used to provide recurring grants for experimental work to researchers associated with the Royal Society, provided they registered their research within a stipulated period and demonstrated their experiments at an annual meeting. In 1726, following a proposal by Sloane, the grants were extended to "strangers" unaffiliated with the Society to encourage "new and useful experiments," though it was only five years later that Stephen Gray became the first such recipient. Prior to Gray, John Theophilus Desaguliers was apparently the only recipient of the grant, but had not always conducted the required annual demonstration.
In November 1736, Martin Folkes, then vice-president of the Society, suggested the Copley grant be converted to "a medal or other honorary prize to be bestowed on the person whose experiment should be best approved...a laudable emulation might be excited among men of genius to try their invention, who in all probability may never be moved for the sake of lucre". On 7 December 1736, the Council of the Royal Society agreed to Folkes' proposal, passing a resolution that the annual Copley grant of five pounds (roughly equivalent to £986 in 2023) be converted to a gold medal "of the same Value, with the Arms of the Society impress’d on it," to be gifted "for the best Experiment produced within the Year, and bestowed in such a manner as to avoid any Envy or Disgust in Rivalship". John Belchier was the first to receive the new award in 1737; due to delays in approving a medal design, however, the medal, designed and struck by John Sigismund Tanner of the Royal Mint, was only presented to Belchier in 1742. Gray and Desaguliers received their medals retrospectively.
Into the early 19th century, medal recipients were selected by the President of the Royal Society, though not always on the basis of publications and experimental demonstrations; political and social connections were also key considerations, along with service in the general interests of the Society. During the long presidency of Joseph Banks, the medal was frequently awarded to recipients whose researches were of a practical or technical nature, involving improvements to scientific equipment or instrument design. In 1831, new regulations adopted by the Royal Society Council made the medal an annual award, dropped the requirement for conducting the qualifying research within a certain period and officially opened it to scientists from any nation; although the medal had previously been awarded to foreign scientists including Alessandro Volta, the majority of recipients had been British subjects. A second donation of £1666 13s. 4d. (roughly equivalent to £212,366 in 2023) was made by Sir Joseph William Copley in 1881, and the interest from that amount is used to pay for the medal.']
reference_answer: In 1831, a significant change regarding the eligibility for the Copley Medal was that new regulations adopted by the Royal Society Council made the medal an annual award and officially opened it to scientists from any nation. This change removed the previous requirement that qualifying research had to be conducted within a certain period and allowed foreign scientists to receive the medal more formally, although some non-British recipients had already been awarded prior to this regulation.

query: What was the significance of Charles Darwin's publication "On the Origin of Species" in relation to the scientific theory it introduced, and how did it challenge existing beliefs about species during the 19th century?
reference_contexts:
['On the Origin of Species (or, more completely, On the Origin of Species by Means of Natural Selection, or the Preservation of Favoured Races in the Struggle for Life) is a work of scientific literature by Charles Darwin that is considered to be the foundation of evolutionary biology. It was published on 24 November 1859. Darwin's book introduced the scientific theory that populations evolve over the course of generations through a process of natural selection, although Lamarckism was also included as a mechanism of lesser importance. The book presented a body of evidence that the diversity of life arose by common descent through a branching pattern of evolution. Darwin included evidence that he had collected on the Beagle expedition in the 1830s and his subsequent findings from research, correspondence, and experimentation.
Various evolutionary ideas had already been proposed to explain new findings in biology. There was growing support for such ideas among dissident anatomists and the general public, but during the first half of the 19th century the English scientific establishment was closely tied to the Church of England, while science was part of natural theology. Ideas about the transmutation of species were controversial as they conflicted with the beliefs that species were unchanging parts of a designed hierarchy and that humans were unique, unrelated to other animals. The political and theological implications were intensely debated, but transmutation was not accepted by the scientific mainstream.
The book was written for non-specialist readers and attracted widespread interest upon its publication. Darwin was already highly regarded as a scientist, so his findings were taken seriously and the evidence he presented generated scientific, philosophical, and religious discussion. The debate over the book contributed to the campaign by T. H. Huxley and his fellow members of the X Club to secularise science by promoting scientific naturalism. Within two decades, there was widespread scientific agreement that evolution, with a branching pattern of common descent, had occurred, but scientists were slow to give natural selection the significance that Darwin thought appropriate. During "the eclipse of Darwinism" from the 1880s to the 1930s, various other mechanisms of evolution were given more credit. With the development of the modern evolutionary synthesis in the 1930s and 1940s, Darwin's concept of evolutionary adaptation through natural selection became central to modern evolutionary theory, and it has now become the unifying concept of the life sciences.


== Summary of Darwin's theory ==

Darwin's theory of evolution is based on key facts and the inferences drawn from them, which biologist Ernst Mayr summarised as follows:

Every species is fertile enough that if all offspring survived to reproduce, the population would grow (fact).
Despite periodic fluctuations, populations remain roughly the same size (fact).
Resources such as food are limited and are relatively stable over time (fact).
A struggle for survival ensues (inference).
Individuals in a population vary significantly from one another (fact).
Much of this variation is heritable (fact).
Individuals less suited to the environment are less likely to survive and less likely to reproduce; individuals more suited to the environment are more likely to survive and more likely to reproduce and leave their heritable traits to future generations, which produces the process of natural selection (fact).
This slowly effected process results in populations changing to adapt to their environments, and ultimately, these variations accumulate over time to form new species (inference).


== Background ==']
reference_answer:
Charles Darwin's publication "On the Origin of Species," released on November 24, 1859, was a groundbreaking work that laid the foundation for evolutionary biology. The significance of this book lies in its introduction of the scientific theory of evolution by natural selection. This theory proposed that populations evolve over generations through a process where individuals with advantageous traits are more likely to survive and reproduce, passing those traits on to future generations.

The publication challenged existing 19th-century beliefs about species in several ways:

1. **Contradiction to Fixed Species Concept**: At the time, the prevailing belief was that species were unchanging parts of a divinely designed hierarchy. Darwin's theory suggested instead that species are not fixed and can change over time through natural processes.

2. **Common Descent**: The book presented evidence for common descent, proposing that all life forms share a common ancestor and have diversified into various branches over time. This idea was in stark contrast to the belief that each species was independently created.

3. **Human Uniqueness Questioned**: Darwin's theory implied that humans were not separate from or superior to other animals but rather part of the same evolutionary process, challenging theological views about human uniqueness and divine creation.

4. **Scientific Naturalism**: The publication contributed to a shift towards scientific naturalism by promoting explanations based on natural processes rather than supernatural intervention. This was part of a broader movement led by figures like T.H. Huxley to secularize science.

5. **Debate and Acceptance**: While initially controversial, especially among the English scientific establishment tied to religious doctrine, Darwin's ideas gradually gained acceptance. By the late 19th century, there was widespread agreement on evolution as a process, although natural selection took time to be fully recognized as its primary mechanism.

Overall, "On the Origin of Species" fundamentally altered the understanding of life and its diversity, setting the stage for modern evolutionary theory and reshaping scientific thought about biology and the natural world.

query: According to Ernst Mayr’s summary of Darwin's theory, what are two key facts that underpin the process of natural selection, and how do these lead to evolutionary change over time?
reference_contexts:
['On the Origin of Species (or, more completely, On the Origin of Species by Means of Natural Selection, or the Preservation of Favoured Races in the Struggle for Life) is a work of scientific literature by Charles Darwin that is considered to be the foundation of evolutionary biology. It was published on 24 November 1859. Darwin's book introduced the scientific theory that populations evolve over the course of generations through a process of natural selection, although Lamarckism was also included as a mechanism of lesser importance. The book presented a body of evidence that the diversity of life arose by common descent through a branching pattern of evolution. Darwin included evidence that he had collected on the Beagle expedition in the 1830s and his subsequent findings from research, correspondence, and experimentation.
Various evolutionary ideas had already been proposed to explain new findings in biology. There was growing support for such ideas among dissident anatomists and the general public, but during the first half of the 19th century the English scientific establishment was closely tied to the Church of England, while science was part of natural theology. Ideas about the transmutation of species were controversial as they conflicted with the beliefs that species were unchanging parts of a designed hierarchy and that humans were unique, unrelated to other animals. The political and theological implications were intensely debated, but transmutation was not accepted by the scientific mainstream.
The book was written for non-specialist readers and attracted widespread interest upon its publication. Darwin was already highly regarded as a scientist, so his findings were taken seriously and the evidence he presented generated scientific, philosophical, and religious discussion. The debate over the book contributed to the campaign by T. H. Huxley and his fellow members of the X Club to secularise science by promoting scientific naturalism.
